questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with a history of decreased vision. Fluorescein angiography showed the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Proliferative diabetic retinopathy

 

  • Image shows neovascularization in proliferative diabetic retinopathy, arising from optic nerve head.
  • Neovascularization of the disc (ND). and along large vessels, as well as neovascularization elsewhere (NVE) present.
  • Treatment for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is photocoagulation of ischaemic areas.
  • Aim is to reduce metabolic demand and prevent release of vasoproliferative factors.

 

 

Birdshot retinochoroidopathy (also known as birdshot chorioretinopathy, vitiliginous chorioretinitis, or simply birdshot uveitis) is a chronic, bilateral, posterior uveitis with characteristic yellow-white lesions in the fundus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mild Non-proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy - Characterized by microaneurysms and retinal hemorrhages but does not feature neovascularization.

 

Option B. Severe Non-proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy - More extensive than mild, including hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and sometimes severe retinal ischemia, but still lacks neovascularization.

 

Option C. Birdshot Choroidopathy - Typically presents with distinctive yellow-white lesions in the retina, which are not apparent in the provided angiography images. This condition is an inflammatory process, not related to neovascularization seen in diabetic retinopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy is the advanced stage of diabetic eye disease, marked by neovascularization, which requires aggressive treatment like laser photocoagulation to prevent severe visual loss. It is crucial for diabetics, particularly those with a long history or poorly controlled diabetes, to undergo regular eye examinations for early detection and management of diabetic retinopathy.

choices.text: Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter
Fluorescein dye - visualised under green filter

questions.text: What is the dye and filter used as seen in the image?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter

 

he most likely correct combination for fluorescein dye visualization is Fluorescein dye - visualized under cobalt blue filter. Fluorescein is a yellow dye that, when applied to the eye, emits a bright green fluorescence when illuminated with blue light from a cobalt blue filter. It's commonly used in ophthalmology to detect corneal abrasions, ulcers, or foreign bodies and to assess contact lens fit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lissamine Green dye - visualized under a green filter: Lissamine Green is a dye that stains devitalized cells and mucous filaments and is used to visualize damage to the conjunctiva and cornea, particularly in dry eye syndrome. It is typically observed under white light, not a green filter, so this combination is not standard.

 

Option C. Lissamine Green dye - visualized under a cobalt blue filter: This is not the standard practice for visualizing Lissamine Green dye. This dye is usually observed under white light, as the cobalt blue filter is specifically used to excite fluorescence from fluorescein dye.

 

Option D. Fluorescein dye - visualized under a green filter: Fluorescein dye is usually visualized under a blue light, not a green filter. When fluorescein is viewed under a green filter, the fluorescence is typically not visible because the green filter would block the green fluorescence emitted by the fluorescein dye.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In ophthalmology, different dyes and filters are used to aid in the diagnosis of various conditions. Fluorescein dye is visualized using a cobalt blue filter, which causes it to fluoresce and highlights areas of corneal compromise. It is crucial to use the appropriate filter for each dye to accurately diagnose and assess ocular surface disorders.

questions.text: Mother had painful vesicular lesions over genitalia one year back. Baby is born with features of meningitis and fever and rashes in abdomen and forearm and died within a week. Scrapings from lesions showed multinucleate giant cells. What is the most likely organism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV2)

 

Explanation

 

  • The correct answer is HSV2 (Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2). The clinical history provided in the question strongly suggests neonatal herpes infection.
  • The mother had a history of painful vesicular lesions over the genitalia, which is characteristic of genital herpes caused by HSV2.
  • Neonatal herpes can be transmitted from the mother to the baby during childbirth if the mother has an active HSV infection.
  • The baby presented with symptoms of meningitis, fever, and rash, which are typical manifestations of neonatal herpes.
  • The presence of multinucleated giant cells on scrapings from lesions further supports the diagnosis, as these are characteristic findings in herpes infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Enterovirus 70:

 

  • Enterovirus 70 is associated with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, not with vesicular lesions or the neonatal symptoms described in the question.
  • It does not typically cause multinucleated giant cells in lesions.

 

Option C. Human Papillomavirus (HPV):

 

  • HPV causes warts and is associated with genital warts, but it does not cause painful vesicular lesions or neonatal meningitis.
  • HPV also does not produce multinucleated giant cells on lesion scrapings.

 

Option D. VZV:

 

  • Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause vesicular lesions, but the clinical scenario described (painful genital lesions in the mother) and the findings in the neonate (multinucleated giant cells and severe systemic symptoms) are more consistent with HSV2 rather than VZV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) is the most likely organism causing neonatal herpes, characterized by the presence of painful vesicular lesions in the mother and severe systemic symptoms including meningitis, fever, and rash in the newborn, along with multinucleated giant cells found in lesion scrapings.

questions.text: Which is the most common lacrimal gland tumor? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pleomorphic adenoma

 

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor.
  • It is also the most common epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland.
  • The most common epithelial tumors, in order of frequency, are as follows:
    1. Benign mixed tumor (BMT), also known as a pleomorphic adenoma (PA)
    2. Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC)
    3. Pleomorphic adenocarcinoma (ACA)
    4. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

 

Note: Most common malignant epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland: Adenoid cystic carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a malignant tumor that can occur in various glands in the body, including the lacrimal gland. It is characterized by slow growth and the tendency to invade nearby structures.

 

Option C. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is another type of malignant tumor that can affect the lacrimal gland. It is characterized by a combination of mucin-secreting and squamous (epidermoid) cells.

 

Option D. Malignant mixed tumor: Malignant mixed tumor, also known as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma, occurs when a previously benign pleomorphic adenoma transforms into a malignant tumor. It is less common than pleomorphic adenoma but represents a more aggressive form of lacrimal gland tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor. It is usually benign and arises from the glandular tissue. It can sometimes have a mixture of cell types, hence the name "pleomorphic."

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented to you with visual acuity of 6/9 in one eye. Further investigations revealed pre-retinal hemorrhages with neovascularization at the optic disc. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pan-retinal photocoagulation

 

The clinical vignette is suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics and the next step in management is pan-retinal photocoagulation.

 

  • Indications for PRP are:
  1. Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy with high-risk characteristics
  2. Neovascularization of iris (NVI)
  3. Severe NPDR associated with:
    • Poor compliance for follow up
    • Before cataract surgery/YAG capsulotomy
    • Renal failure
    • One-eyed patient
    • Pregnancy
  • It is done using Yellow – Green spectrum laser - double frequency Nd YAG (532) laser or argon or diode laser.

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy is used to describe retinal changes seen in diabetic patients. It is classified into the following types:

  • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • Diabetic maculopathy
  • Advanced diabetic eye disease

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal laser photocoagulation: Focal laser photocoagulation is used to treat specific areas of retinal edema, particularly in cases of diabetic maculopathy. It is not the first choice for treating PDR with high-risk characteristics.

 

Option C. Grid laser photocoagulation: Grid laser photocoagulation is also used to treat diffuse macular edema by applying laser burns in a grid pattern. It is not indicated for the treatment of PDR with neovascularization.

 

Option D. Scleral buckling: Scleral buckling is a surgical procedure used to repair retinal detachment. It is not appropriate for treating PDR with neovascularization and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the recommended management for proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics such as neovascularization at the optic disc and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

questions.text:
Which of these options are considered direct gonioscopes?(INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Goldmann
  2. Richardson
  3. Zeis
  4. Koeppe
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

Richardson and Koeppe are direct gonioscopes.

 

DIRECT GONIOSCOPY - It is performed with a steep convex lens which permits light from the angle to exit the eye closer to the perpendicular at the lens - air interface. These lenses are used with an operating microscope.

 

DIRECT GONIOSCOPE IMAGE

 

 

Examples –

 

  • Koeppe goniolens
  • Richardson- Shaffer's lens
  • Sieback goniolens
  • Worth goniolens
  • Swan Jacob's lens
  • Huskins barkan's lens

 

INDIRECT GONIOSCOPY - uses mirrors or prism to overcome the problem of total internal reflection. Moreover, it uses the slit lamp's illumination and magnification system to its advantage.

 

INDIRECT GONIOSCOPE IMAGE

 

 

Examples –

 

  • Goldmann Gonioprism
  • Zeis Gonioprism
  • Tokel Gonioprism

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct gonioscopes like Richardson and Koeppe provide a detailed and direct view of the anterior chamber angle, which is valuable in diagnostic and certain therapeutic procedures.

choices.text: Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of double vision, drooping of his right eyelid, and difficulty swallowing, especially in the evening hours. He mentions that his symptoms are mild in the morning but worsen throughout the day, making it hard for him to keep his eyes open and causing slurred speech by late afternoon. He denies any history of trauma, recent infections, or significant changes in his medications. His medical history includes hypertension, managed with lifestyle modifications. During the examination, the physician notices right-sided ptosis and weakness in the extraocular muscles without any sensory loss or abnormal pupillary reflexes. The physician decides to administer a short-acting medication intravenously to assess the response, and within minutes, the patient’s symptoms improve significantly, with resolution of ptosis and improved speech clarity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Myasthenia Gravis

 

Explanation:

 

Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness due to the destruction of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction by autoantibodies. Patients typically present with symptoms that worsen with activity and improve with rest, such as ptosis, diplopia, and bulbar symptoms including dysphagia and slurred speech. In this patient’s case, the classic pattern of worsening symptoms throughout the day and improvement after rest is highly suggestive of MG. The dramatic response to anticholinesterase medications, like edrophonium, confirms the diagnosis by temporarily increasing acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, which improves muscle strength. Additional tests, including the ice pack test and acetylcholine receptor antibody testing, can further support the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome: This condition is associated with antibodies against presynaptic calcium channels, leading to impaired acetylcholine release. Symptoms often include proximal muscle weakness that improves with activity, unlike MG, and it does not show significant improvement with anticholinesterase medications.

 

Option B. Botulism: Botulism results from a neurotoxin that inhibits acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction, causing descending paralysis, ptosis, and dysphagia. However, it typically progresses more rapidly and does not respond to anticholinesterase medications. Autonomic features such as fixed, dilated pupils are also characteristic but are not present in this case.

 

Option D. Multiple Sclerosis: Multiple Sclerosis is a central nervous system demyelinating disorder presenting with varied neurological symptoms such as optic neuritis, motor deficits, and sensory changes. Ocular symptoms in MS are not characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness that improves with anticholinesterase medications, distinguishing it from MG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is marked by fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with exertion and improves with rest, particularly affecting ocular and bulbar muscles. Diagnosis is confirmed by clinical presentation, response to anticholinesterase medications, and tests such as acetylcholine receptor antibodies and Single Fiber Electromyography.

questions.text: The spectacles shown in the image are not used for the management of which of the following? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypermetropia

 

The image shows a bifocal spectacle that is made of lenses with two different optical powers (upper half for distant vision and lower half for near vision). Hypermetropia, or farsightedness, primarily affects near vision, necessitating correction that provides a uniform optical adjustment across the entire lens surface to assist with close vision tasks, rather than segmented correction like in bifocals.

 

Other Options:

 

Bifocal spectacles are typically used for treating following conditions:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bifocal spectacles are not typically used for treating hypermetropia, which generally requires a uniform optical correction across the entire lens to aid in near tasks. Bifocals are instead beneficial in conditions requiring simultaneous correction for near and far vision, such as presbyopia, or specific needs following surgical interventions like in aphakia and pediatric pseudophakia.

questions.text: Following instrument is used to measure: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proptosis

 

The image shows a Hertel exophthalmometer, which is specifically designed to measure proptosis—the forward displacement of the eye. 

 

This instrument directly measures how much the eyeball protrudes forward from the eye socket. It is essential in diagnosing conditions like thyroid eye disease where proptosis is a common feature.

 

  • Design and Use: It consists of a ruler and two lateral mirrors or prisms that align with the lateral orbital rim, allowing for accurate measurement of the anterior position of the cornea relative to the lateral orbital wall.
    1. Bilateral Assessment: The Hertel exophthalmometer can measure the protrusion of both eyes simultaneously, allowing for comparison between the two. This is vital for identifying asymmetrical proptosis, which can be an indicator of more serious unilateral orbital disease.
    2. Quantitative Data: It provides quantitative data that can help in monitoring the progression or resolution of orbital diseases over time. This is particularly useful in tracking the effectiveness of treatment for conditions that cause proptosis.
    3. Simple and Non-invasive: The device is straightforward to use and non-invasive, making it a patient-friendly tool for regular follow-up assessments in clinical settings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Hertel exophthalmometer is a specialized tool for assessing the extent of proptosis in conditions affecting the orbit and surrounding tissues, helping guide further diagnostic and therapeutic steps for conditions like thyroid eye disease.

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is shown in the image given below? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior ethmoidal nerve block

 

The procedure shown in the given image is an anterior ethmoidal nerve block.

 

The anterior ethmoidal nerve supplies the roof of the nasal cavity. It is a branch of the Nasociliary nerve which in turn is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve (V1). It is sometimes used in endonasal surgery.

 

Detailing the Procedure:

 

  • Purpose: Used predominantly to numb the area for surgical procedures within the nasal cavity.
  • Method: Involves injection near the anterior ethmoidal foramen to block the nerve that transmits sensation from the nasal roof.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasolacrimal duct syringing: This procedure is used to check the patency of the nasolacrimal duct. It involves flushing the duct with saline to check for blockages, typically conducted by inserting a syringe into the puncta near the medial canthus of the eye. However, this is not related to the procedure shown in the image since it involves the eye directly and is performed with the eyes open to access the puncta.

 

Option C. Infraorbital nerve block: This block anesthetizes the area supplied by the infraorbital nerve, which affects the lower eyelid, upper lip, and cheek. It is generally performed via an intraoral approach at the infraorbital foramen, located below the orbit, which is not depicted in the image.

 

Option D. Trephination of the frontal sinus: This surgical procedure involves making an incision in the floor of the frontal sinus to facilitate drainage. This procedure targets a different anatomic location and involves surgical tools, not the approach shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An anterior ethmoidal nerve block is crucial for numbing the nasal cavity area, particularly in endonasal surgeries. It is essential for procedures requiring detailed work near the roof of the nasal cavity, reflecting the significance of understanding the specific nerve anatomy for effective anesthesia.

choices.text: Retinal pigmentation
Pale waxy disc
Narrowing of vessels
ERG – normal

questions.text: What among the following is not true about retinitis pigmentosa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. ERG – normal

 

ERG is abnormal in retinitis pigmentosa.

 

  • Retinitis pigmentosa is a primary pigmentary retinal dystrophy predominantly affecting the rods more than the cones.
  • It is the most common hereditary fundus dystrophy, with the most common mode of inheritance being autosomal recessive.
  • In early disease, it shows reduced scotopic rod and combined responses, and photopic responses reduce with progression.
  • Eventually, the ERG becomes extinguished.
  • The characteristic visual symptom is night blindness, which may present several years before visible changes in the retina appear.
  • Dark adaptation is affected, and tubular vision may occur in advanced cases.
  • Fundus changes include bone-spicule retinal pigmentation, arteriolar attenuation, and 'waxy' disc pallor.

 

  • Visual field changes-
    • Annular or ring-shaped scotoma is a typical feature which corresponds to the degenerated equatorial zone of retina. As the disease progresses, scotoma increases anteriorly and posteriorly and ultimately only central vision is left (tubular vision). Eventually even this is also lost and the patient becomes blind.

 

  • Electrophysiological changes-

1. Electro-retinogram (ERG) is subnormal or abolished.

2. Electro-oculogram (EOG) shows absence of light peak.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Pale Waxy Disc: Optic disc pallor due to progressive degeneration.

 

Option C. Narrowing of Vessels: Attenuation of retinal arterioles due to retinal thinning and atrophy.

 

Option D.  ERG (Electroretinogram: ERG is not normal in retinitis pigmentosa. It shows abnormal findings, such as:

  • Early Disease: Reduced scotopic (rod) response and combined responses.
  • Progression: Reduced photopic (cone) responses.
  • Advanced Disease: ERG becomes extinguished or abolished

 

Educational Objective:

 

In retinitis pigmentosa, the ERG is not normal; it shows progressive abnormalities reflecting the degeneration of photoreceptor cells. Other features include retinal pigmentation, pale waxy disc, and narrowing of retinal vessels.

questions.text: What is the typical weight range of rabbits used in ophthalmological research? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. 1.5-2.5 kg

 

Explanation:

 

Rabbits used in ophthalmological experiments generally weigh between 1.5 to 2.5 kg. This weight range is ideal for handling and conducting precise ophthalmological studies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.5-1 kg - This weight range is too low for typical ophthalmological research involving rabbits.

 

Option C. 5-7 kg - This weight range is too high and not common for ophthalmological studies using rabbits.

 

Option D. 10-12 kg - This weight range is also too high and not suitable for standard ophthalmological experiments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The typical weight range for rabbits used in ophthalmological research is 1.5-2.5 kg, making them suitable for handling and detailed eye studies.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions do you see punched-out lesions of the retina? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxoplasmosis

 

Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic infection caused by Toxoplasma gondii that affects the central nervous system and retina in humans.

 

It can occur as 3 forms:

 

  1. Congenital: infants are typically born with inactive disease, and doctors may observe healed punched-out chorioretinal lesions in the macular region.
  2. Acquired: can also result in similar punched-out lesions, along with punctate outer retinal toxoplasmosis.
  3. Recurrent Toxoplasmosis: Patients may experience multiple episodes of retinal inflammation, leading to further accumulation of these punched-out lesions over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior staphyloma: This refers to an outpouching or deformation of the posterior shell of the eye, often associated with severe myopia but not characterized by punched-out lesions.

 

Option B. Fundal coloboma: A congenital malformation resulting in missing pieces of tissue in structures forming the eye, such as the choroid and retina, which does not typically present as punched-out lesions.

 

Option C. Congenital rubella: While it can cause retinal changes, the signature features often include salt and pepper retinopathy rather than punched-out lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appearance of punched-out lesions in the retina is crucial for diagnosing toxoplasmosis. This understanding can aid in distinguishing toxoplasmosis from other infectious or congenital conditions that affect the retina, guiding appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

choices.text: To find out the axis in astigmatism

questions.text: You can use a stenopaeic slit for all of the following except? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corneal tattooing

 

Stenopaeic slit is not used in corneal tattooing.

 

Corneal tattooing was introduced as an attempt to mask the leukomatous opacities of the eye during ancient times. Corneal tattooing is also found to reduce glare within the eye due to iris loss and increase visual acuity.

 

Many different types of inks are used throughout history and today for the dyeing of the cornea. Today, India ink is the most commonly used, providing safe and long-lasting effects, but other dyes include metallic colors in powder form, various organic dyes, and uveal pigment from animal eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fincham's test: Used specifically to evaluate differences in the nature of halos seen by patients, aiding in the differential diagnosis between cataract and glaucoma.

 

Option C. Optical Iridectomy: The stenopaeic slit assists in locating the best area on the cornea for performing an iridectomy, essential in cases where peripheral vision needs to be preserved.

 

Option D. To find out the axis in astigmatism: It is instrumental in determining the precise axis for corrective lenses, which is vital for proper astigmatism management.

 

STENOPAEIC SLIT

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uses of stenopaeic slit test:

 

  • Fincham's test: to differentiate between the colored halos due to cataract and corneal edema due to glaucoma.
  • To find out the optimal site for optical iridectomy in case of corneal opacities.
  • To find out the axis in astigmatism.

questions.text: A patient has presented for a routine eye evaluation. You have checked his visual acuity using Snellen's chart and found it to be 6/6. What is the minimum angle of resolution? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5 minutes of arc

 

The angle subtended for a patient with 6/6 vision is 5 minutes of arc.

 

Visual acuity is a measure of the spatial resolution of the eye or an estimation of its ability to discriminate between two points.

 

Snellen's chart consists of a series of letters arranged in lines, each diminishing in size. Each whole letter will subtend the angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point of the eye at the given distance.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum angle of resolution for someone with a visual acuity of 6/6 using a Snellen chart is 5 minutes of arc. This indicates the precise and detailed visual capability required to resolve fine details at a standard distance, a fundamental concept in understanding and assessing visual acuity in clinical settings.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Soft exudate, Central retinal vein occlusion

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with progressive painless loss of vision presents to the ophthalmology OPD. Fundus picture of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding and the cause of it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hard exudate, Diabetes mellitus

 

The given image shows small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with discrete margins that are suggestive of hard exudates, seen in diabetic macular edema.

 

 

COTTON WOOL SPOT vs HARD EXUDATE

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy

 

 

Hypertensive retinopathy

 

 

Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) – Fundoscopy reveals massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins. Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soft exudate, Hypertension: Soft exudates, also known as cotton wool spots, are whitish fluffy spots with indistinct margins.

 

They occur around infarcted areas and result from swelling of nerve fiber layer axons.

 

Associated with hypertensive retinopathy, toxaemic retinopathy of pregnancy, diabetic retinopathy, anemias, and collagen disorders like discoid lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, and scleroderma.

 

Option C. Flame-shaped hemorrhages, Hypertension: Flame-shaped hemorrhages are superficial retinal hemorrhages that occur due to disruption of the capillaries in the retinal nerve fiber layer.

 

They are seen in diabetic retinopathy, non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion, traumatic retinopathy, Eale's disease, hypertensive retinopathy, and anemic retinopathy.

 

Option D. Soft exudate, Central retinal vein occlusion: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is characterized by massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins.

 

Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus.

 

Soft exudates can be seen in CRVO but are not the primary finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hard exudates are characteristic findings in diabetic retinopathy, indicating chronic localized edema and composed of leaked lipoproteins and lipid-filled macrophages. They present as small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with distinct margins in the retina.

questions.text: Identify the site of the lesion: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left occipital lobe

 

  • The visual field defect is right homonymous hemianopia with macular-sparing.
  • It is caused by lesions of the left occipital lobe, which is contralateral/crossing of fibers.
  • Head injury is a common cause of such lesions.
  • These lesions may be associated with visual hallucinations, denial of blindness (Anton syndrome), and the Riddoch phenomenon.
  • These lesions are commonly due to occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery. The part of the occipital lobe representing the peripheral field vision is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.
  • The lesions generally spare the central vision/macular vision since the area at the tip of the calcarine cortex, representing the central macular vision, is supplied by a branch of the middle cerebral artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Occipital Lobe: This would cause a left-sided homonymous hemianopia.

 

Option C. Left Geniculate Body: Lesions here typically produce similar visual field defects as occipital lobe lesions but may have different associated clinical signs and symptoms.

 

Option D. Optic Chiasma: Lesions at the optic chiasm typically produce bitemporal hemianopia, which is not demonstrated in the visual field tests provided.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the left occipital lobe is the most likely cause of the right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing shown in the visual field tests. This understanding is critical for accurately diagnosing the underlying condition, potentially a vascular event, and directing appropriate management and intervention strategies.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency and his ocular examination reveals the following. Which of the following is not done initially? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Removal of the foreign body

 

The image shows an eye with a metallic foreign body causing a penetrating injury. In such cases, immediate removal of the foreign body is not recommended as an initial step because doing so may exacerbate the injury or lead to complications such as infection or further mechanical damage to the eye structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Proper Initial Steps Include:
 

Option B. Check for visual acuity: This helps assess the extent of damage to the eye's visual function and provides a baseline for future comparisons.

 

Option C. Give antibiotics: Prophylactic treatment to prevent infection, especially considering the risk introduced by the foreign object.

 

Option D. Do primary survey: Ensures that the patient's overall health and other potential life-threatening conditions are addressed (part of the ABCDE approach - Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure).

 

Further Management:

 

CT scan: To precisely locate the foreign body and any possible penetration into the orbital or cranial cavities, helping plan for surgical intervention.

 

Avoid MRI: Due to the risk of movement of the metallic object, which can cause more damage.

 

Surgical exploration and repair in the operating theatre: To safely remove the foreign body under controlled conditions, minimizing risk of further damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ocular injuries involving foreign bodies, immediate removal is not advised due to the potential for further damage. Initial steps should focus on assessment, stabilization, and prevention of infection, followed by careful planning and execution of the foreign body removal under appropriate surgical conditions.

choices.text: Relative afferent pupillary defect

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of hypertension and poorly controlled diabetes presents to his ophthalmologist with complaints of gradually worsening vision in both eyes over the past year. His intraocular pressure is found to be elevated, and fundoscopy reveals optic disc cupping with nerve fiber layer thinning. Based on this finding, which of the following pupillary abnormalities is most commonly associated with primary open-angle glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Relative afferent pupillary defect

 

Explanation:

 

A relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), also known as a Marcus Gunn pupil, is an important clinical sign in primary open-angle glaucoma, indicating asymmetric optic nerve damage. It occurs when the affected eye has a defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex. During the swinging flashlight test, the pupil of the affected eye dilates slightly when the light is shone on it, instead of remaining constricted as it would in a normal response. This finding reflects early and often asymmetric optic nerve damage seen in glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Light-near dissociation
Light-near dissociation is characterized by pupils that do not constrict in response to light but do constrict during accommodation, commonly seen in conditions like Argyll Robertson pupil and Parinaud syndrome. It is not typically associated with glaucoma.

 

Option C. Anisocoria
Anisocoria refers to unequal pupil sizes and can be physiological or related to various neurological conditions. It does not specifically indicate optic nerve damage or glaucoma.

 

Option D. Horner’s syndrome
Horner’s syndrome is characterized by ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis due to sympathetic pathway disruption. It does not involve the optic nerve or the afferent pathway and is unrelated to glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is a key clinical finding in primary open-angle glaucoma that signals asymmetric optic nerve damage. This condition is identified by the swinging flashlight test, which shows an abnormal pupillary response, reflecting the impact of glaucoma on the optic nerve pathways.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of angle-closure glaucoma has been diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Which of the following drugs have to be avoided in this patient? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amitriptyline

 

  • Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that is known to have marked anticholinergic activity.
  • TCAs have high affinity for muscarinic acetylcholine (M type) receptors, causing the subsequent blockade of these receptors.
  • Blocking of these receptors can result in decreased outflow of aqueous humour, leading to an increase in intraocular pressure.
  • This effect can exacerbate pre-existing angle-closure type glaucoma, which is already characterized by impaired drainage of aqueous humour.
  • Therefore, amitriptyline is a drug to be avoided in patients with angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B and D: Sertraline and Fluvoxamine are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors with no activity at the muscarinic cholinergic receptors and therefore have no effect on the outflow of aqueous humor and thereby, on the intraocular pressure.

 

Option C: Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that is a serotonin-norephedrine reuptake inhibitor with the ability to precipitate angle-closure glaucoma by itself; however, due to lack of any activity at the muscarinic cholinergic receptors, it does not increase the intraocular pressure to the extent that Amitriptyline does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with angle-closure glaucoma, medications with anticholinergic properties, such as Amitriptyline, should be avoided due to their potential to increase intraocular pressure and exacerbate the condition.

questions.text: What was ETDRS study related to? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diabetic Macular edema

 

  • Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) was a clinical trial.
  • The study investigated the effect of photocoagulation on diabetic macular edema.
  • The study demonstrated that focal photocoagulation was beneficial in treating diabetic macular edema.
  • The study recommended that eyes with clinically significant diabetic macular edema should be considered for focal photocoagulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central retinal artery occlusion: Not the focus of the ETDRS; this condition involves sudden, painless vision loss due to an occlusion in the central retinal artery.

 

Option C. Primary open angle glaucoma: Not related to the ETDRS, which did not address glaucoma treatments or outcomes.

 

Option D. Non-infectious uveitis: Also unrelated to the ETDRS, as the study was specific to diabetic retinopathy and macular edema, not inflammatory eye diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ETDRS study established the beneficial effects of photocoagulation in treating diabetic macular edema, recommending it as an early treatment option to prevent vision loss in patients with clinically significant macular edema.

questions.text:
Which of the following helps to differentiate a fixed dilated pupil? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Phenylephrine
  2. 1% Pilocarpine
  3. 0.1% Pilocarpine
  4. Cocaine 0.5%
  5. Epinephrine
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3 only

 

Pilocarpine is used to differentiate fixed dilated pupils.

 

2. 1% Pilocarpine

 

 

3. 0.1% Pilocarpine

 

 

Other Options:

 

1. Phenylephrine: This is a sympathomimetic agent that typically dilates the pupil and is not used for differentiating causes of fixed dilation.

 

4. Cocaine 0.5%: Cocaine tests for anisocoria primarily in the context of Horner’s syndrome. It blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine, failing to dilate a Horner’s pupil due to sympathetic chain lesion.

 

 

Note - Cocaine and 1% hydroxy amphetamine are used to evaluate anisocoria in smaller pupil.

 

 

5. Epinephrine: Similar to phenylephrine, epinephrine is not used to differentiate fixed dilated pupils but rather to induce dilation for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pilocarpine at concentrations of 1% and 0.1% is crucial for differentiating causes of fixed dilated pupils, with 1% identifying pharmacological blockade or nerve palsy, and 0.1% detecting hypersensitivity in cases like Adie's pupil.

questions.text: Extra row of eyelashes behind the grey line is called as? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Distichiasis

 

Distichiasis refers to the additional row of eyelashes behind the grey line. It may happen as a result of inherited or acquired factors.

 

The cornea may become irritated by these lashes. The treatment involves separating the lids and applying cryotherapy to the hair follicles' bases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichiasis: Refers to the misdirection of eyelashes that grow inward towards the eye, causing irritation and potential damage to the cornea. The lid margin remains in its normal position.

 

Option C. Tylosis: Refers to the thickening of the tarsal plate, often associated with chronic inflammation and lid margin disease, but not related to an extra row of eyelashes.

 

Option D. Madarosis: Refers to the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows, which can be due to various causes including trauma, systemic diseases, and dermatologic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Distichiasis is the condition where an extra row of eyelashes grows behind the normal lash line, often leading to corneal irritation and requiring treatment such as cryotherapy or electrolysis to prevent complications.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in rheumatoid arthritis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Febuxostat

 

Febuxostat is not used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor primarily used as a hypouricemic agent for managing gout by reducing uric acid production. Its primary function is to alleviate the symptoms and prevent the recurrence of gout, not to treat inflammatory or autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Leflunomide: Incorrect choice for the given answer as Leflunomide is indeed used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) that works by suppressing the immune system to reduce inflammation.

 

Option C. Methotrexate: Incorrect because Methotrexate is a cornerstone treatment for rheumatoid arthritis. It is another DMARD that helps reduce joint damage and decrease the pain and swelling associated with RA.

 

Option D. Etanercept: Incorrect as it is also used in rheumatoid arthritis treatment. Etanercept is a TNF (tumor necrosis factor) inhibitor, which is a type of biologic therapy that helps to decrease inflammation and slow disease progression in RA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Febuxostat is specifically used to manage gout by lowering uric acid levels and does not have a role in the treatment regimen for rheumatoid arthritis, which typically involves DMARDs and biologic agents aimed at controlling systemic inflammation and preventing joint damage.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/RA/Chap 358

questions.text: A patient is prescribed a corrective lens with the following prescription: -1D spherical, -2D cylinder at 180 degrees. What type of refractive error is being corrected? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) With the rule astigmatism

 

  • In the context of refractive errors corrected by lenses, here's an explanation of each type of astigmatism as mentioned:

 

In this condition, the eye's steepest curve is oriented vertically (up and down). This is the most common type of astigmatism. The -2D cylindrical correction at 180 degrees indicates that the correction is applied horizontally, which compensates for the steeper vertical curvature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Against the Rule Astigmatism: Here, the steepest curvature is horizontal (side to side). Corrective lenses for this type would have cylindrical axes oriented vertically (usually at 90 degrees).

 

Option C. Simple Astigmatism: This occurs when one principal meridian is emmetropic (normal), meaning no refractive error, while the other has myopia (short-sightedness) or hyperopia (long-sightedness). There is only one refractive error to correct.

 

Option D. Mixed Astigmatism: This type features one meridian with myopia and the perpendicular meridian with hyperopia. Essentially, one axis is near sighted, and the other is farsighted, requiring complex lens corrections to address both issues simultaneously.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When prescribed corrective lenses for astigmatism, understanding the orientation and type of astigmatism (with the rule, against the rule, simple, or mixed) is crucial for ensuring the correct lens type and orientation is used, thus maximizing visual clarity and health.

choices.text: The parts of a pterygium are Body, head and cap

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of pterygium? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rate of recurrence is 95%

 

  • Pterygium is a triangular fibrovascular ingrowth of degenerative conjunctival tissue.
  • It is caused by prolonged exposure to UV rays, dry heat, etc.
  • It has three parts: head (apical part on the cornea, body (region between limbus and canthus), and cap (semilunar white infiltrate in front of the head).
  • Patients may experience itching and grittiness due to Dellen.
  • It can interfere with vision and induce astigmatism.
  • Stocker's line may be associated with pterygium, which is a linear deposition of iron seen in the corneal epithelium, anterior to the head of a pterygium.
  • The recurrence rate after simple surgical excision is around 80%.

 

 

  • Pterygium is of 2 types: 
    1. Progressive which is thick, fleshy, and vascular.
    2. Regressive which is thin, atrophic, and attenuated.
  • This condition can be treated symptomatically with tear substitutes for dry eye symptoms and patients are advised to avoid  exposure to sun.
  • Surgical excision with free conjunctival limbal autograft is the preferred treatment to avoid recurrence.
  • The recurrence rate of pterygium is around 80% after simple surgical excision. Excision together with adjunctive therapies such as mitomycin C or 5-fluorouracil can reduce the risk of recurrence to approximately 10%.
  • Reported Recurrence rate after P.E.R.F.E.C.T technique is 1.6% (Cornelius CR. Recurrence Rate and Complications of Pterygium Extended Removal Followed by Extended Conjunctival Transplant).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is a fibrovascular growth: This is accurate. Pterygium consists of fibrovascular tissue that can progressively invade the cornea.

 

Option C. The parts of a pterygium are Body, head and cap: This is true. The pterygium is typically described as having three parts: the head (which is the part that extends onto the cornea), the body (the main bulk of the growth), and the cap or leading edge.

 

Option D. Has progressive and regressive types: This is also true. Pterygium can be classified into progressive, which is active, vascular, and may encroach further onto the cornea, and regressive, which is typically less vascular and more fibrotic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygium's recurrence after surgical removal depends greatly on the surgical technique and the use of adjuvant therapies, not inherently 95% as previously thought. Effective management includes surgical excision combined with conjunctival autografts and adjuvant therapy to reduce the risk of recurrence significantly.

choices.text: Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery
Right gastric and left gastric artery
Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels
Right gastric and short gastric vessels

questions.text: Ligation of the common hepatic artery would most likely compromise the blood supply to which of the following arteries? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery

 

Ligation of the common hepatic artery will cause impairment in the blood supply through its branches i.e., right gastric artery and right gastroepiploic artery.

 

 

  • The common hepatic artery typically divides into the hepatic proper artery and the gastroduodenal artery.
  • The hepatic proper artery, in turn, gives rise to the right gastric artery (which supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach) and continues as the left and right hepatic arteries for the liver.
  • The gastroduodenal artery gives off the right gastroepiploic artery, which supplies the greater curvature of the stomach.
  • Thus, if the common hepatic artery is ligated, blood supply to both the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries would be impaired.

 

Branches of hepatic artery (Mnemonic – Girls R So Cute)

 

  • Gastroduodenal artery > divides into right gastroepiploic and superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries.
  • Right gastric artery
  • Supra duodenal artery (inconstant)
  • Cystic artery

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right gastric and left gastric artery: While the right gastric artery does arise from the hepatic proper artery (a branch of the common hepatic artery), the left gastric artery arises directly from the celiac trunk. Ligation of the common hepatic artery would not affect the left gastric artery's blood supply.

 

Option C. Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels: The right gastroepiploic artery arises from the gastroduodenal artery (a branch of the common hepatic artery). The short gastric arteries, however, typically arise from the splenic artery, another direct branch of the celiac trunk. Therefore, ligation of the common hepatic artery would not affect the blood supply of the short gastric vessels.

 

Option D. Right gastric and short gastric vessels: As mentioned earlier, the right gastric artery arises from the hepatic proper artery. The short gastric arteries arise from the splenic artery. Ligation of the common hepatic artery would only affect the right gastric artery's blood supply, not the short gastric vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligation of the common hepatic artery affects the blood supply to both the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries due to their derivation from the hepatic proper and gastroduodenal arteries respectively.

choices.text: DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue
Upsetting of receptors so no treatment is required

questions.text: A patient came to the medical OPD with complaints of polyuria. He has a history of undergoing total hypophysectomy. His Na+ levels are found to be 155 mEq/L, urine osmolality was 200 mOsm/L. What is the definitive management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. DDAVP supplementation for lifelong

 

The patient's presentation of polyuria and low urine osmolality (200 mOsm/L) with hypernatremia (Na+ 155 mEq/L) is indicative of diabetes insipidus (DI). Given the history of total hypophysectomy, this is most likely central diabetes insipidus (CDI), where the pituitary gland no longer produces antidiuretic hormone (ADH, also known as vasopressin).

 

In CDI, the definitive treatment is desmopressin (DDAVP), a synthetic analog of ADH. Desmopressin helps to reduce urine output and correct hypernatremia by promoting water reabsorption in the kidneys. Since the condition is permanent due to the hypophysectomy, lifelong supplementation with desmopressin is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue: Discontinuing DDAVP after 2 weeks is not appropriate as the patient will continue to suffer from polyuria and hypernatremia due to the lack of ADH.

 

Option C. Upsetting of receptors so no treatment is required: This option is incorrect as the patient's symptoms and lab findings clearly indicate the need for treatment.

 

Option D. Thiazides for 2 weeks: Thiazides are used in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) to reduce urine output by increasing ADH sensitivity. However, in central diabetes insipidus, thiazides are not effective because the issue is the absence of ADH, not a problem with the kidneys' response to it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with central diabetes insipidus following total hypophysectomy, lifelong desmopressin (DDAVP) supplementation is required to manage symptoms and prevent complications from persistent polyuria and hypernatremia.

choices.text: Horizontal gaze palsy
3rd nerve palsy

questions.text: The given image illustrates which of the following conditions? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia

 

Explanation:


The image shows an attempt at lateral gaze away from the lesion side, where the abducting eye overshoots the target, leading to dissociated nystagmus. This feature is characteristic of internuclear ophthalmoplegia, where there is a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus, disrupting communication between the abducens nucleus and the contralateral medial rectus subnucleus. This condition affects the adduction of the ipsilateral eye during saccades, causing either slow or absent movement. If the internuclear ophthalmoplegia is bilateral, the abduction saccades may also be impaired.

 

Other options:


Option A. Horizontal gaze palsy: This condition involves the inability to move both eyes in the same direction, typically without the dissociated nystagmus seen in internuclear ophthalmoplegia.
 

Option C. Third nerve palsy: It is usually associated with symptoms like ptosis, eye deviation down and out, and pupil dilation, none of which are seen in the image provided.
 

Option D. Duane retraction syndrome: This is a congenital condition where the eye movement is restricted due to abnormal development of the cranial nerves. The findings in the image do not align with this condition's characteristic restricted abduction or adduction.

 

Educational Objective:


Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is characterized by impaired adduction of the affected eye and dissociated nystagmus in the abducting eye during lateral gaze.

questions.text: Which of the following is not useful for hemoglobin estimation by the colorimetric test?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RBC pipette

 

The RBC pipette, identifiable by its red bead, is primarily used for counting red blood cells in a blood sample. It is not suitable for the colorimetric estimation of hemoglobin, as it is not designed for colorimetric comparisons or for mixing the reagents involved in this method.

 

Other Options:

 

The colorimetric method for hemoglobin estimation, often referred to as Sahli's method, relies on comparing the color intensity of a hemoglobin solution to a standard comparator. The primary steps involve mixing a blood sample with N/10 HCl in a graduated hemoglobin tube, which then undergoes color comparison against a brown glass standard.

 

Key Tools Used in Sahli's Method:

 

Option B. Sahli graduated hemoglobin tube: Used to mix blood with hydrochloric acid and measure the resulting color intensity.

 

Option C. Comparator with brown glass standard: Helps in comparing the color of the hemoglobin solution to determine the concentration.

 

Option D. Hemoglobin pipette: Utilized to accurately measure and transfer the blood sample into the graduated hemoglobin tube.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The RBC pipette is not useful for hemoglobin estimation by the colorimetric (Sahli's) method, as it is designed for cell counting rather than for the preparation and color comparison required in this test.

 

Summary Table:

questions.text: Condition shown below is due to which vitamin deficiency?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

This is Bitot’s spot shown in the picture due to vitamin A deficiency. There is build-up of keratin located superficially in conjunctiva. This can be oval, triangular or irregular in shape. This is also associated with conjunctival xerosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B:

 

  • Function: Vitamin B is a group of vitamins that includes B1 (thiamine), B2 (riboflavin), B3 (niacin), B5 (pantothenic acid), B6 (pyridoxine), B7 (biotin), B9 (folate), and B12 (cobalamin). These vitamins play various roles in energy production, brain function, and cell metabolism
  • Deficiency Symptoms: Deficiencies in different B vitamins can result in a range of symptoms, including fatigue, neurological issues, anemia, and skin problems.

 

Option C. Vitamin C:

 

  • Function: Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen, wound healing, and the absorption of iron from plant-based foods. It also acts as an antioxidant, protecting cells from damage.
  • Deficiency Symptoms: A lack of vitamin C can lead to scurvy, which includes symptoms such as bleeding gums, joint pain, and skin issues.

 

Option D. Vitamin K:

 

  • Function: Vitamin K is crucial for blood clotting and bone health. It helps in the synthesis of proteins involved in clot formation and bone mineralization.
  • Deficiency Symptoms: Vitamin K deficiency can result in bleeding disorders and weakened bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Function: Vitamin A plays a vital role in the growth and development of human cells, controlling the immune system by preventing infections, and activating white blood cells
  • Deficiency Symptoms: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to night blindness, dry skin, poor immune function, and impaired growth and development.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 530

questions.text: Which of the following is a new approved drug for Rett syndrome. (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trofinetide

 

Rett syndrome is an X-linked genetic disorder mostly seen in females. Symptoms include impairments in language and coordination, and repetitive movements. It occurs due to mutation in MECP2 gene.

 

Trofinetide is an analog of glypromate or glycine–proline–glutamate (GPE), a naturally occurring protein in the brain and the N-terminal tripeptide of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1). GPE exhibits neuroprotective properties: it protects neurons from glutamate-mediated excitotoxicity and oxidative stress.

 

Trofinetide has similar neuroprotective properties and has longer half-life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zavegepant: This is a CGRP antagonist approved for the treatment of migraine, not for Rett syndrome.

 

Option C. Sparsentan: This is a dual endothelin antagonist and angiotensin receptor antagonist approved for the treatment of IgA nephropathy, not Rett syndrome.

 

Option D. Elacestrant: This is a selective estrogen receptor downregulator approved as an oral treatment for breast cancer, not Rett syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trofinetide is a newly approved drug for Rett syndrome, exhibiting neuroprotective properties similar to those of glypromate (GPE), and is beneficial for treating the symptoms of this genetic disorder.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Abductor hallucis
  2. Flexor digitorum accessorius
  3. Flexor hallucis brevis
  4. First lumbrical
  5. First interossei
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 5

 

 

 

The lateral plantar nerve is a branch of the tibial nerve, which innervates various muscles in the sole of the foot. It divides into superficial and deep branches, each supplying specific muscles.

 

  • Flexor Digitorum Accessorius : This muscle assists in the flexion of the toes and is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.
  • First Interossei: The interossei muscles, which include the dorsal and plantar interossei, are responsible for abduction and adduction of the toes. The first interossei is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Abductor hallucis: This muscle is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, not the lateral plantar nerve.

 

3. Flexor hallucis brevis: This muscle is also supplied by the medial plantar nerve.

 

4. First lumbrical: The first lumbrical is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, whereas the second, third, and fourth lumbricals are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral plantar nerve supplies the flexor digitorum accessorius (quadratus plantae) and the first interossei muscles in the foot.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the surgeon with a recurrent inguinal hernia. The surgeon decides to perform a hernioplasty, and the patient inquiries about the most appropriate type of mesh to be used. The surgeon wants to ensure that the patient is aware of the various types of meshes that can be used in hernioplasty. Which of the following is the most appropriate mesh for use in hernioplasty? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lightweight mesh with large pores

 

Lightweight meshes with large pores are considered the most appropriate choice for hernioplasty. They provide adequate support to repair the hernia while allowing for better tissue integration and reduced inflammation. This type of mesh is associated with lower postoperative pain and discomfort.

 

Heavyweight mesh:

 

  • Heavyweight meshes are typically not recommended for hernioplasty because they can lead to increased inflammation, tissue response, and a higher risk of complications. They may cause stiffness and discomfort in the area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most appropriate mesh to use in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores.
  • Lightweight meshes induce a less-pronounced foreign body reaction and decreased inflammatory response, leading to better tissue incorporation, increased prosthesis compliance, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.
  • Meshes with large pores allow for increased soft tissue ingrowth and exhibit less inflammatory infiltrate, connective tissue, and scar bridging. This results in less adhesion, better tissue incorporation, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.
  • “Meshes with thinner strands and larger spaces (pores) between them are preferred because they have better tissue integration, less contracture, less foreign body reaction, more flexibility and improved comfort.” Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1063.
  • Meshes used in hernioplasty can be synthetic or biological, with synthetic meshes made from Polypropylene, Polyester, or PTFE.

questions.text: Mrs. Kumar, a 60-year-old woman, has been experiencing difficulty swallowing and a feeling of pressure in her chest. Her doctor orders an ultrasound, which reveals a retrosternal goiter. The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Neck

 

Explanation:

 

The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via the neck. This is because the thyroid gland is anatomically located in the neck, and even when a goiter extends behind the sternum into the chest, the neck provides the most direct and least invasive access for surgical removal. The retrosternal portion of the goiter can usually be mobilized and delivered into the neck for excision without the need for more invasive thoracic approaches. The vascular supply of the goiter also predominantly comes from cervical vessels like the inferior thyroid artery, making the neck approach feasible and effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chest: Surgical approaches through the chest are typically not used for retrosternal goiters. Accessing the thyroid gland through the chest would involve more invasive procedures, such as thoracotomy, and is generally reserved for rare cases with specific indications, such as very large goiters extending deeply into the chest cavity.

 

Option C. Median Sternotomy: Median sternotomy involves cutting through the breastbone (sternum) to access structures within the chest, particularly the heart and major blood vessels. While median sternotomy is common for cardiac surgeries, it is not the primary approach for treating retrosternal goiters, which can typically be addressed via the neck.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because the neck is the commonest and preferred approach for the surgical removal of retrosternal goiters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common and preferred surgical approach for a retrosternal goiter is via the neck due to its direct access to the thyroid gland and the feasibility of mobilizing the goiter from this region.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of an old lady who sustained a fall and presented with a headache and neurological symptoms a few days later? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subdural Hematoma

 

The given clinical scenario suggests Acute Subdural Hematoma (SDH), which is the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura, resulting from the tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the Dural sinuses. It is commonly seen in the elderly, alcoholics, and patients on anticoagulants. The stretching of Cortical-Dural bridging veins in cerebral atrophy makes them vulnerable to rupture, leading to symptoms of raised intracranial pressure or focal deficits. On head CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped lesion.

 

A subdural hematoma is a collection of blood between the layers of the dura mater surrounding the brain. It can occur as a result of head trauma, such as a fall, and may not present with immediate symptoms but can lead to a gradual onset of neurological symptoms, including headache, confusion, and other focal neurological deficits. Subdural hematomas are known to have delayed presentations after the initial trauma, making this the likely diagnosis in the context of a fall with subsequent neurological symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multi-infarct dementia: Multi-infarct dementia, also known as vascular dementia, typically develops gradually and is associated with a history of multiple strokes or cerebral infarctions. It does not typically present acutely after a fall with neurological symptoms.

 

Option B. Frontal lobe meningioma: While a frontal lobe meningioma can cause neurological symptoms, it typically develops slowly and is not usually associated with an acute presentation following a fall. Additionally, the symptoms of a meningioma can vary widely depending on its location and size.

 

Option C. Korsakoff disease: Korsakoff disease is primarily associated with chronic alcohol abuse and is characterized by severe memory impairment. It does not typically present acutely following a fall with neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the history of a fall and the delayed onset of neurological symptoms, a subdural hematoma (option D) is the most likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: Klenow fragment lacks the activity of? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5'-3' Exonuclease

 

DNA polymerase I (Kornberg’s enzyme) was isolated from Escherichia coli. It is a repair enzyme. It has both 3′ to 5′ and 5′ to 3′ exonuclease activities. When 5′ to 3′ exonuclease domain is removed, the remaining fragment retains the polymerization and proofreading activities; it is then called Klenow fragment. It is widely used in recombinant DNA technology.

 

Details of DNA Polymerase I and Klenow Fragment:

  • DNA Polymerase I (Kornberg's enzyme): This enzyme has three activities:
    • 5'->3' polymerase activity (synthesizes DNA)
    • 3'-5' exonuclease activity (proofreading)
    • 5'-3' exonuclease activity (removes RNA primers and repairs DNA)

  • Klenow Fragment: This fragment results from removing the 5'-3' exonuclease domain. It retains:

     

The Klenow fragment is widely used in recombinant DNA technology due to its ability to synthesize DNA and proofread without degrading the DNA template or newly synthesized strand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3'-5' Exonuclease: This proofreading activity is retained by the Klenow fragment.

 

Option C. 5'->3' DNA polymerase: This polymerization activity is also retained by the Klenow fragment.

 

Option D. 3'-5' DNA polymerase: This option is incorrect terminology; which is correctly termed 3'-5' exonuclease and is retained in the Klenow fragment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase I lacks the 5'-3' exonuclease activity but retains the 5'->3' polymerase and 3'-5' exonuclease (proofreading) activities, making it useful for DNA synthesis and recombinant DNA technology.

choices.text: Left Optic Nerve
Right Occipital Lobe

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of progressive difficulty seeing objects in his peripheral vision, particularly noticing that he often misses things on the sides while driving. He reports experiencing mild, intermittent headaches over the past few weeks. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he has no known history of trauma or other neurological issues. A visual field test is performed, and the results are displayed in the image provided. Based on these findings, what is the most likely location of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B. Optic Chiasma

 

The visual field defect observed in the image is characteristic of bitemporal hemianopia, which is typically caused by a lesion at the optic chiasma. The optic chiasma is the point where the optic nerves from both eyes partially cross, and a lesion here affects the crossing fibers that correspond to the temporal (lateral) visual fields of both eyes. The most common cause of such a lesion is a pituitary gland tumor, which can compress the optic chiasma as it enlarges. Other potential causes include suprasellar aneurysms, craniopharyngiomas, and meningiomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left Optic Nerve: A lesion here would result in monocular vision loss or partial vision loss in the left eye only, not the bitemporal hemianopia seen in this case.

 

Option C. Right Occipital Lobe: A lesion here would typically result in a contralateral homonymous hemianopia (loss of the same side of the visual field in both eyes), not a bitemporal hemianopia.

 

Option D. Left Temporal Lobe: A lesion in the left temporal lobe would affect the superior quadrants of the visual field on the right side in both eyes (superior homonymous quadrantanopia), not the pattern seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitemporal hemianopia, typically resulting from a lesion at the optic chiasma, is most commonly caused by pituitary tumors. Identifying this visual field defect is crucial as it can be a sign of a potentially serious underlying condition that requires further investigation and management.

choices.text: Weakly basic drugs
Weakly acidic drugs

questions.text: Alkalinization of urine will be helpful in the treatment of poisoning due to?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Weakly acidic drugs

 

Alkalinization of urine is effective in treating overdoses of weakly acidic drugs. By increasing the pH of the urine, it promotes the ionization of these drugs. Ionized drugs are less likely to be reabsorbed in the kidney tubules and are more readily excreted. This principle is particularly applied in cases of aspirin (salicylate) poisoning.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Weakly basic drugs: Urinary alkalinization is not typically used for weakly basic drugs. Basic drugs are more likely to be reabsorbed in an alkaline environment, making this approach counterproductive.

 

Option B. Strong acids: Strong acids are not significantly affected by urinary pH, so alkalinization would not be particularly beneficial.

 

Option C. Strong bases: Similar to strong acids, strong bases are not significantly impacted by changes in urinary pH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkalinization of urine is an effective strategy to enhance the excretion of weakly acidic drugs by increasing their ionization and reducing their reabsorption in the renal tubules, thus promoting their elimination from the body. This method is particularly useful in cases of poisoning with weak acids, such as aspirin (salicylates).

choices.text: Teriparatide can be given along with bisphosphonates.
Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year
Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day
Oral vitamin D3 is given along with oral calcium

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal female patient with a history of Colle's fracture comes to the outpatient department complaining of lower back pain. After undergoing a bone density test, her T score is found to be -2.5. Which of the following statements about the management of her condition is incorrect? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year

 

This question deals with osteoporotic post-menopausal female, who has a history of fracture as well.

 

Bisphosphonates which act by inhibiting the bone resorption by the osteoclasts form the first line of treatment in this patient. Bisphosphonates are DOC for Osteoporosis (Steroid induced, post-menopausal and due to any reason). These are indicated for 5 years and then a drug holiday of 2-3 years is given to avoid adverse effects (increased risk of bone fractures and osteonecrosis of mandible). These can be repeated for another 5 years after drug holiday.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teriparatide can be given along with bisphosphonates: Teriparatide is a parathyroid hormone analog that stimulates bone formation by increasing osteoblast activity. It is particularly useful in patients with severe osteoporosis and a history of fractures. It can be started before bisphosphonates in certain cases.

 

Option C. Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day: The recommended daily intake of calcium for postmenopausal women is around 1200 mg. This helps maintain bone density and prevent further bone loss.

 

Option D. Oral vitamin D3 is given along with oral calcium: Supplementation with oral vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) along with calcium is essential to ensure proper calcium absorption and to maintain bone health. The recommended dose of vitamin D3 is typically around 800 IU per day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bisphosphonates are recommended for up to 5 years, not just one year, in the treatment of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women.

questions.text:
All of the following statements about proto-oncogenes are true except? (AIIMS MAY 2021)

 

  1. BRCA1 is an oncogene.
  2. HER2neu is amplified only in a fraction of breast cancer.
  3. EGFR (+) is seen in non-small cell lung cancer.
  4. N-MYC is a tumor suppressor gene.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4

 

Statement 1: BRCA1 is an oncogene.


This is false. BRCA1 is not an oncogene; it is a tumor suppressor gene. Mutations in BRCA1 are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers, but its normal function is to help repair DNA damage, thereby preventing cancer formation.

 

Statement 4: N-MYC is a tumor suppressor gene.


This is false. N-MYC is not a tumor suppressor gene; it is a proto-oncogene. N-MYC is involved in the regulation of cell growth and division. Amplification of the N-MYC gene is commonly seen in neuroblastoma and small-cell carcinoma of the lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: HER2neu is amplified only in a fraction of breast cancer.


This is true. HER2 (also known as ERBB2) is a proto-oncogene that is amplified in approximately 15-20% of breast cancers. This amplification leads to overexpression of the HER2 protein, which promotes cell proliferation and survival.

 

Statement 3: EGFR (+) is seen in non-small cell lung cancer.


This is true. EGFR (Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor) is often overexpressed or mutated in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), leading to uncontrolled cell growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene (involved in DNA repair) and N-MYC is a proto-oncogene (associated with development of neuroblastoma).

 

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition 521-528

questions.text: Calculate the anion gap from the following values: Na+ = 137 mmol/L; K+ = 4 mmol/L; CI- =100 mmol/L; HCO3- = 15 mmol/L? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 22 mmol/L

 

AG = (Sum of cation) - (Sum of anion)

 

AG = (Na - (HCO3 + CL))

 

AG = 137 – 115 = 22 mmol/L

 

Note: Normal AG ~ 12

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Environmental enteropathy
Celiac disease
Whipple's disease

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. Duodenal biopsy of the patient showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

 

The clinical presentation and histopathological findings point to celiac disease.

 

Celiac disease is sometimes referred to as celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. In genetically predisposed individuals, it is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by the consumption of gluten-containing cereals such as Barley, Rye, Oat & Wheat (BROW)

 

Almost all celiac disease patients have the class II HLADQ2 or HLA-DQ8 allele.

 

Histopathology: Increased numbers of intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis), crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy characterize the histopathology.

 

 

  • Prior to biopsy, noninvasive serologic tests are usually performed. The presence of IgA antibodies to tissue transglutaminase or IgA or IgG antibodies to deamidated gliadin is the most sensitive test. Anti-endomysial antibodies are more specific than other antibodies but less sensitive.
  • Clinical features: -
    • Malabsorption syndrome with chronic refractory anemia, chronic diarrhea, bloating, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss. A characteristic itchy, blistering skin lesion, dermatitis herpetiformis, can be present in as many as 10% of patients, and the incidence of lymphocytic gastritis and lymphocytic colitis is also increased.
    • Enteropathy associated T cell lymphoma
    • Small intestinal adenocarcinoma

 

Treatment – Gluten free diet results in symptomatic improvement for most patients, but a gluten-free diet may also reduce the risk of long-term complications including anemia, female infertility, osteoporosis, and cancer.

 

DAPSONE for dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Environmental enteropathy: Environmental enteropathy / tropical sprue is seen in tropical areas with poor sanitation. It is believed to be caused by one or more infectious agents that respond to antibiotics. Mucosa shows variable villous atrophy. Folic acid and B12 deficiency is common.

 

Option C. Whipple's disease: Whipple's disease is a multisystemic disease caused by T. whipplei. Small intestinal biopsy shows PAS-positive macrophages (see image below).

 

 

Option D. Chronic pancreatitis: Causes malabsorption due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. Not associated with the specific histopathological features seen in celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease is characterized by malabsorption, diarrhea, poor appetite, crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy, and increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes. It is diagnosed by serologic tests and confirmed with a duodenal biopsy. Treatment includes a strict gluten-free diet.

questions.text: A patient presenting with bleeding gums and easy bruisability was diagnosed with scurvy. What is the biochemical basis of scurvy?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defective collagen formation

 

Scurvy is a condition caused by a deficiency of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), which is essential for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues in the synthesis of collagen. Collagen is a crucial protein for the structural integrity of connective tissues, including blood vessels, skin, and gums. In the absence of sufficient vitamin C, collagen synthesis is impaired, leading to weakened blood vessels, bleeding gums, and easy bruising..

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low calcium levels do not cause scurvy; they may contribute to other clinical conditions like Muscle cramps and stiffness, Tingling and Numbness, Tetany.

 

Option C. Vitamin K deficiency leads to the inhibition of clotting factors and cause bleeding tendencies.

 

Option D. Vitamin A deficiency causes hyperkeratosis and epithelial changes, such as xerosis and Bitot's spots, and night blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet
Tubing near mouth and nose
Bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method of administering free-flow oxygen in a neonate?  (INICET MAY 2024)
