questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet

 

Free-flow oxygen refers to the administration of oxygen without the need for positive pressure ventilation. It is typically used to provide supplemental oxygen to neonates who are breathing spontaneously.

 

  • Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet: This method allows oxygen to flow freely into the mask and can provide free-flow oxygen.
  • Face mask: Using a face mask can administer free-flow oxygen effectively.
  • Tubing near mouth and nose: Placing oxygen tubing near the mouth and nose is a common method to deliver free-flow oxygen.

 

However, bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet does not provide a means for oxygen to flow freely. This method relies on positive pressure ventilation, where the bag is squeezed to push air (and oxygen if connected) into the neonate's lungs, not allowing for the passive flow of oxygen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet: This method allows oxygen to flow through the inlet, providing free-flow oxygen.

 

Option B. Face mask: A face mask can be used to deliver free-flow oxygen effectively.

 

Option C. Tubing near mouth and nose: This is a standard method for administering free-flow oxygen to neonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Free-flow oxygen can be administered using methods that allow passive flow of oxygen, such as a face mask or tubing near the mouth and nose. Bag and mask ventilation without an oxygen inlet does not allow for free-flow oxygen administration.

questions.text: The following table gives BP values before and after administration of drug 'X'. What would be the probable mechanism of action of drug 'X'? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. β1 agonist and β2 agonist

 

The drug's likely mechanism of action is β1 and β2 agonism.

 

Due to its action on β1 receptors, there is an increase in the HR of the patient and also of the SBP (Increase in HR leads to an increase in the CO upto a certain extent). The agonistic action on the β2 receptors causes vasodilation and leads to a fall in the DBP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. α1 agonist and β1 agonist: α1 agonists typically cause vasoconstriction, which would increase both SBP and DBP. This does not align with the observed decrease in DBP.

 

Option B. M2 agonist and M3 agonist: M2 and M3 receptor agonism would likely lead to bradycardia and increased gastrointestinal motility, respectively. They do not explain the observed increase in HR and SBP, nor the decrease in DBP.

 

Option C. α1 antagonist and β2 agonist: While α1 antagonism could contribute to a decrease in DBP through vasodilation, it would not typically cause an increase in SBP and HR, which are more specifically associated with β1 agonism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of increased systolic blood pressure, decreased diastolic blood pressure, and increased heart rate suggests that drug 'X' acts as a β1 and β2 agonist, leading to increased cardiac output and vasodilation.

questions.text: Laboratory investigations of a patient being evaluated for jaundice show elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. Levels of the remaining liver enzymes are normal. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Obstructive jaundice

 

The laboratory findings indicate elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels while other liver enzymes are normal. This pattern is most consistent with obstructive jaundice.

 

In this condition, there is an obstruction in the bile ducts that prevents bile from being excreted into the intestine, leading to an accumulation of conjugated bilirubin in the blood. Alkaline phosphatase is typically elevated in conditions that involve cholestasis (impaired bile flow), which is characteristic of obstructive jaundice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemolytic jaundice: This type of jaundice is caused by the excessive breakdown of red blood cells, leading to elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin. Alkaline phosphatase levels remain normal in hemolytic jaundice.

 

Option C. Hepatic jaundice: Hepatic jaundice occurs due to liver cell damage, which impairs the liver's ability to process and excrete bilirubin. This condition typically shows elevated transaminases (ALT, AST), not just alkaline phosphatase.

 

Option D. Prehepatic jaundice: This term is often used interchangeably with hemolytic jaundice, where the problem lies before the bilirubin reaches the liver. Elevated unconjugated bilirubin and normal alkaline phosphatase levels are seen in prehepatic jaundice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where laboratory investigations reveal elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase with normal other liver enzymes, obstructive jaundice should be considered as the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Indications for surgery (including biopsy) in a patient with Potts spine are all except: (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cold abscess without neurological involvement

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The tubercular spread to spine usually takes place from Lungs > lymph nodes.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

 

 

 

  • Clinical features: 
    • Back pain, usually minimal, is the commonest and 1st symptom.
    • Tenderness is the earliest sign.
    • Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension – Coin test
    • Earliest sign of neurological deficit – increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response.
    • The prominence of 2-3 spinous process, called angular kyphosis is commonest in tuberculosis because of 2 contiguous vertebra involved with paradiscal destruction.
    • In the thoracic region, kyphosis is most marked because of normal kyphotic curvature.

 

 

  • Tuberculosis is the most common cause of cold abscess.
  • Imaging:

 

1. Plain radiograph:

 

  • Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm.
  • Reduction of disc space
  • Vertebral body destruction
  • Paravertebral abscess
  • Widening of mediastinum

 

2. CT scan:

 

  • It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray; may indicate precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.

 

3. MRI:

 

  • Investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
  • It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.

 

 

4. Biopsy:

 

  • CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.
  • Stages of TB Spine with Neural Deficit:

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Middle path regimen is used in India
    • Treatment is done with antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on nonoperative management but if indications of surgery exist then, surgery needs to be done.
       
  • Stage-wise Treatment:

 

 

  • ATT: 
    • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
    • Minimum duration is 9–12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18–24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB the duration of ATT is 6 months–1 year).|
       
  • Indications of surgery in any disease of spine:
    1. Bowel bladder involvement
    2. Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
    3. No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks
    4. Paravertebral abscess
    5. Spine instability due to kyphotic deformity (kyphotic angles 50-60° or more which is likely to progress)
    6. Pott’s spine resistant to current anti-tuberculosis drugs
    7. To prevent/treat complications like late-onset paraplegia
       
  • Surgical options for most of the cases are anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
  • Hong Kong operation is also carried out for Pott’s spine.
  • Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed).

 

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

 

Note:

 

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.
  • Prognostic Factors:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Presence of cold abscess without any neurological involvement is not an indication for biopsy or surgical treatment of Pott’s spine.
  • Neurological involvement which is deteriorating with time is an important indication for surgical intervention.

choices.text: Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate
Add sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine
Continue corticosteroids and methotrexate
Start only anti-TNF alpha agents

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is being treated with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids for the past 4 months. However, the disease is still progressing. What would be your recommendation for the further management of this patient? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Add sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine

 

Adding sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine to the treatment regimen for a patient with rheumatoid arthritis who is not responding adequately to methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids is a sound strategy. This approach follows the principle of combining different disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) to achieve better disease control. Both sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine are DMARDs that work by different mechanisms to reduce inflammation and slow disease progression in rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate: While switching to parenteral administration can increase the effectiveness of methotrexate for some patients, it might not be sufficient alone if the disease is still progressing.

 

Option C. Continue corticosteroids and methotrexate: Continuing the same treatment without modification is not advisable if the disease is actively progressing, as this indicates that the current regimen is insufficient.

 

Option D. Start only anti-TNF alpha agents: While anti-TNF agents are effective for many patients, they are typically used after trying combination DMARD therapy, especially in cases not severe enough to warrant immediate biologic therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient with rheumatoid arthritis does not respond adequately to initial therapy with methotrexate and corticosteroids, the addition of other DMARDs such as sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine can be beneficial.

 

Drugs:

 

  • Methotrexate: Start 10mg/week → max 25mg/week along with Folic acid twice/week
  • Check ocular fundus before HCQ initiation
  • Leflunomide, sulfasalazine other group of drugs.
  • Sulfasalazine is safe in pregnancy !!
  • Symptomatic relief with NSAID and short course corticosteroids.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatoid arthritis/ Chap 358

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of redness, itching, and irritation at the corners of his eyes for the past week. He reports that these symptoms started gradually and have been worsening, especially after frequent rubbing. He also notices some discharge that accumulates at the corners of his eyes, which sometimes appears foamy. On examination, there is inflammation and mild excoriation at the inner canthi with no signs of corneal involvement. The rest of his ocular exam, including visual acuity and pupillary response, is normal. The physician suspects an infection and plans to start appropriate treatment after identifying the causative organism.

Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C. Moraxella lacunata

 

Explanation:

 

Moraxella lacunata is a gram-negative diplobacillus that is the most common causative organism of angular conjunctivitis. This condition is characterized by inflammation, irritation, and a foamy or sticky discharge localized at the inner or outer corners of the eyes. The infection often originates from nasal secretions that spread to the eyes via contaminated hands or objects. Moraxella species are frequently found in the nasal passages of healthy individuals, and when transferred to the eyes, they cause localized canthal inflammation. Treatment typically involves topical antibiotics such as oxytetracycline, with a course lasting 10 to 14 days, which effectively resolves the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corynebacterium species: While Corynebacterium can cause chronic conjunctivitis, it does not typically present with localized canthal inflammation or foamy discharge. The clinical features seen here are more consistent with angular conjunctivitis caused by Moraxella.

 

Option B. Streptococcus viridans: Streptococcus viridans is generally associated with endophthalmitis or other ocular infections, but it does not typically cause the localized angular inflammation and discharge seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus epidermidis: Staphylococcus epidermidis is a common cause of chronic blepharitis and conjunctivitis, often associated with biofilm formation on eyelid margins or ocular surfaces, rather than the distinct canthal involvement and discharge typical of Moraxella-related angular conjunctivitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Moraxella lacunata is the leading cause of angular conjunctivitis, characterized by localized inflammation and discharge at the corners of the eyes. The infection spreads from nasal secretions to the eyes via contaminated hands, and the preferred treatment is topical antibiotics, typically oxytetracycline, administered for 10 to 14 days.

questions.text: From the options given below, which of these does not belong to the category of cardiac poison?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Atropa belladonna  

 

Atropa belladonna is not considered a cardiac poison. It is known for its anticholinergic properties and is part of the Solanaceae family, which includes Datura stramonium and Hyoscyamus niger. The active principles in these plants include atropine, hyoscine (scopolamine), and hyoscyamine, which exhibit anticholinergic effects.

 

Atropa Belladona

 

  • Solanaceae family: Datura stramonium, Atropa belladonna (deadly nightshade) and Hyoscyamus niger (henbane) all belong to same family Solanaceae

  • Anticholinergic alkaloids: All of these plants have similar alkaloids, and all of these alkaloids have anticholinergic properties.

  • Active Principles: Examples of important active principles found in these alkaloids are Atropine, Hyoscine (scopolamine), Hyoscyamine.

  • Align and symptoms: All of these have similar anticholinergic sign and symptoms, especially delirium.

  • Atropa Belladona have black berries as shown below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aconite: Aconite is a cardiac poison. It affects the heart by causing arrhythmias and other cardiac disturbances.

 

Option B. Cerbera thevetia: Cerbera thevetia, also known as yellow oleander, is a well-known cardiac poison. It contains cardiac glycosides that affect the heart's rhythm and contractility.

 

Option C. Nicotiana tabacum: Nicotiana tabacum, or tobacco, contains nicotine, which has significant effects on the cardiovascular system, including causing hypertension and tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac Poisons (Mnemonic: DHONAQ)

  • Digitalis Purpurea (Digitalis)

  • HCN

  • Oleander (Kaner): 

         > White Oleander (Nerium Odorum)

         > Yellow Oleander (Cerebra Thevetia)

  • Nicotiana Tobaccum (Nicotine, Tobacco)

  • Aconite (Monk’s Hood, Mitha Zaher)

  • Quinine (Cinchona Plant)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent stimulator of naive T-cells? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mature dendritic cells

 

Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulator of naive T cells as they possess higher levels of MHC-II. They also have costimulatory membrane proteins which are required for activation of T cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Follicular dendritic cells are functionally different from dendritic cells. They are not antigen-presenting-cells and do not activate naive T cells.

 

 

Option C. B lymphocytes: While B cells can act as antigen-presenting cells, they are not as effective as dendritic cells in stimulating naive T cells. They typically present antigens to already activated T cells rather than naive ones.

 

Option D. NK cell: Natural killer (NK) cells are involved in the innate immune response and do not function as antigen-presenting cells. They are responsible for recognizing and killing virally infected cells and tumor cells without the need for antigen presentation.

 

Educational Objective:


Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulators of naive T cells due to their high levels of MHC-II and costimulatory molecules.

questions.text: Which skull foramen is formed by 3 bones?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Foramen lacerum

 

Explanation:

 

The foramen lacerum is a triangular-shaped foramen located in the skull base. It is largely filled with cartilage in a living individual and serves as a landmark rather than a conduit for significant neurovascular structures (though some smaller emissary veins and nerves might pass through). Importantly, the internal carotid artery courses superiorly to this foramen but doesn't pass through it. The foramen lacerum is bordered by three bones:

 

  • Petrous part of the temporal bone: This bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • Sphenoid bone: The greater wing of the sphenoid bone forms the anterior and lateral aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • Basilar part of the occipital bone: The basilar part of the occipital bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.

 

The foramen lacerum is covered by a fibrous membrane, which makes it difficult to see and access.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foramen magnum: The foramen magnum is the largest foramen of the skull and is located in its base. Through it pass the medulla oblongata (which becomes the spinal cord as it exits the skull), the vertebral arteries, spinal parts of the accessory nerves, and the anterior and posterior spinal arteries. It is formed entirely by the occipital bone.

 

Option C. Foramen rotundum: The foramen rotundum is located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. Through this foramen, the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve (V2) exits the cranial cavity to enter the pterygopalatine fossa. It is formed solely by the sphenoid bone.

 

Option D. Foramen jugulare (jugular foramen): The jugular foramen is a large irregular opening located between the petrous part of the temporal bone and the occipital bone. This foramen transmits the internal jugular vein and several cranial nerves: the glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), and accessory (XI) nerves. It is formed by two bones:

 

  1. Anterolaterally: the petrous part of the temporal bone.
  2. Posteromedially: the occipital bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The foramen lacerum's formation by three bones (the petrous part of the temporal bone, greater wing of the sphenoid bone, and basilar part of the occipital bone) makes it unique among the foramina at the base of the skull. Understanding its anatomical context and relations is crucial for interpreting imaging and planning surgeries involving the cranial base.

questions.text:
A teenage girl presented with irregular cycles and increased facial hair. Her ovaries showed increased volume. Which of the following are used in the first line treatment? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Laparoscopic ovarian drilling
  2. Anti-androgens
  3. Lifestyle modifications
  4. Combined oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:


The clinical presentation of irregular menstrual cycles and increased facial hair, combined with increased ovarian volume, is suggestive of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The first-line treatment options for PCOS typically include:

 

Anti-androgens (2): These medications help reduce symptoms related to excess androgens, such as facial hair and acne. Common examples include spironolactone.

 

Lifestyle modifications (3): These are crucial for managing PCOS. Weight loss and exercise can improve insulin sensitivity and help regulate menstrual cycles.

 

Combined oral contraceptive pills (4): These are used to regulate menstrual cycles, reduce hyperandrogenism symptoms (like hirsutism), and provide endometrial protection.

 

Other Options:

 

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling (1): This is a surgical procedure used to treat PCOS, but it is generally considered a second-line treatment. It is typically performed when medical management fails to achieve the desired results.

 

Educational Objective:


The first-line treatments for PCOS include anti-androgens, lifestyle modifications, and combined oral contraceptive pills.

 

Ref: Page no 460, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A patient who was receiving warfarin therapy for atrial fibrillation was prescribed a cephalosporin antibiotic to treat a lower respiratory tract infection. He returned to the hospital after developing hemarthrosis. Which of the following cephalosporins is most likely to have caused this? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cefoperazone

 

  • The development of hemarthrosis (bleeding into a joint) in a patient on warfarin therapy, after starting a cephalosporin antibiotic, raises concerns about drug interactions that can potentiate the anticoagulant effect of warfarin.
  • Warfarin inhibits the enzyme Vitamin K Epoxide Reductase (VKOR) which in turn inhibits the gamma carboxylation of Glutamic acid residues of factors II, VII , IX and X.
  • Cefoperazone is a 3rd generation cephalosporin that contains methylthiotetrazole (MTT) group. This also inhibits the VKOR enzyme, just like warfarin. Therefore, in a patient who is already on warfarin therapy, this can lead to bleeding manifestations.
  • Cefotetan, Cefamandole are other cephalosporins that contain the MTT group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cefixime: This is a third-generation cephalosporin and is not known to have a significant interaction with warfarin that would increase the risk of bleeding.

 

Option C. Ceftobiprole: As a newer cephalosporin, ceftobiprole is not commonly associated with significant interactions with warfarin that would lead to increased bleeding risk.

 

Option D. Ceftazidime: This is another third-generation cephalosporin, and like cefixime, it is not commonly associated with interactions that significantly enhance the anticoagulant effect of warfarin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cefoperazone is the cephalosporin most likely to cause hemarthrosis in a patient on warfarin therapy due to its MTT group, which can inhibit the VKOR enzyme and potentiate the anticoagulant effects of warfarin. Other cephalosporins like cefixime, ceftobiprole, and ceftazidime do not have this interaction and are less likely to cause such bleeding complications.

questions.text: The instrument given in the image is: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Jackson-Pratt drain

 

The image displays a Jackson-Pratt (JP) drain, which is a type of closed drainage system used in post-surgical procedures. This device comprises a flexible bulb connected to tubing, creating negative pressure to gently suction fluid from the wound or surgical site. The bulb can be compressed and then sealed to initiate suction, allowing controlled drainage and reducing the risk of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Romovac drain: Romovac drains are commonly used after various surgical procedures, including abdominal surgeries, breast surgeries, orthopedic surgeries, and others. They are also utilized in the treatment of abscesses and some types of traumatic injuries. They are a closed drainage system.

 

 

Option C. Minivac drain – (Mini in size): A closed suction drain is placed under your skin during surgery. This drain removes any blood or other fluids that might build up in this area.

 

 

Option D. Corrugated drain: Corrugated drains are intended for open passive drainage, used in situations where wounds must be kept open. They are placed directly into the wounds left to heal by secondary intent. 

 

 

Educational Objective : 

 

The Jackson-Pratt drain is a closed drainage system that uses gentle suction to remove fluids from surgical sites, helping prevent fluid accumulation and reducing infection risk.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of redness, tearing, and a mild foreign body sensation in her right eye for the past few days. She reports no significant ocular history but mentions recent symptoms of fever, cough, and anosmia. She has no known allergies or history of eye trauma. Her visual acuity is unaffected, and there is no pain with eye movement. On examination, there is mild conjunctival injection without discharge or chemosis. The ophthalmologist is concerned about the possibility of a systemic viral infection. What is the most common ocular manifestation associated with the suspected viral infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Follicular conjunctivitis

 

Explanation:

 

Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation observed in patients with COVID-19. The virus affects the eyes due to the presence of ACE-2 receptors on the cornea and conjunctiva, which act as entry points for SARS-CoV-2. Follicular conjunctivitis appears as mild conjunctival redness with or without discharge, and it can occasionally be the only symptom of COVID-19, highlighting the virus's potential to impact the eyes. Other ocular symptoms include tearing, itching, and a foreign body sensation, but follicular conjunctivitis remains the predominant ocular finding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Episcleritis: Episcleritis is a localized, benign inflammation of the episclera often associated with autoimmune conditions rather than viral infections like COVID-19. It presents with mild redness and discomfort, which can be mistaken for conjunctivitis but is less common in COVID-19.

 

Option B. Anterior uveitis: Anterior uveitis is characterized by inflammation of the iris and ciliary body, leading to photophobia, pain, and visual disturbances. It is not commonly associated with COVID-19 and would present with different symptoms such as eye pain and photophobia, unlike the mild conjunctivitis observed.

 

Option D. Keratitis: Keratitis involves inflammation of the cornea and can present with severe pain, photophobia, and vision changes. This condition is not a common manifestation of COVID-19 and typically has more severe symptoms compared to follicular conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation seen in patients with COVID-19. It is crucial for healthcare providers, especially ophthalmologists, to be aware of this presentation and to consider COVID-19 testing in patients with unexplained conjunctival symptoms, including
 
Most common ocular symptoms: Dry eye or foreign body sensation, redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.

 

Most common ocular manifestation: Mild follicular conjunctivitis, which can appear as the only sign and symptom of COVID-19.

 

Other less frequent ocular complications: Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, episcleritis, chemosis, and photophobia.

 

Intraocular complications that may occur: Retinal artery occlusions, hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy.

 

Patients with conjunctivitis should undergo a nasopharyngeal RT-PCR test for COVID-19 to rule out systemic infection.

 

Physicians and ophthalmologists should exercise caution when examining patients with conjunctivitis and wear eye-protective gear in addition to face masks and other protective devices.

questions.text: A clinician is conducting a study on the occurrence of a rare disease within a specific population over a certain time period. The disease cases occur independently, and the average rate of occurrence is constant. Which statistical distribution best represents the likelihood of observing a specific number of disease cases within this defined time period? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Poisson distribution

 

Poisson Distribution

 

  • It is a ‘discrete probability distribution’ that expresses the ‘probability of a number of events occurring in a fixed period of time’ (if these events occur with a known average rate and independently of the time since the last event).
  • It can also be used for the number of events in other specified intervals such as distance, area or volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Binomial distribution is used for those events which can only have two possible results given as yes or no / success or failure. It is usually done for finite number of events unlike Poisson’s distribution.

 

Option B. Gaussian distribution and Option D. Normal distribution is the distribution of values of a quantitative variable such that they are symmetric with respect to a middle value with same mean, median and mode, and then the frequencies taper off rapidly and symmetrically on both sides – ‘bell shaped distribution’.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Poisson distribution is used to model the number of rare disease cases occurring independently in a fixed period of time.

questions.text: Which of the following is wrong regarding primary and secondary immune response? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

The given statement that antibody affinity is higher in the primary immune response and lower in the secondary immune response is incorrect. The correct comparison should be:

 

  • Primary Immune Response: This occurs as a result of the first contact with an antigen. It typically involves a longer lag period (4-10 days) before antibodies are produced. The initial antibodies produced are primarily IgM, with lower affinity for the antigen.
  • Secondary Immune Response: This occurs as a result of subsequent exposures to the same antigen. It involves a shorter lag period (1-3 days) due to the presence of memory cells. The antibodies produced are primarily IgG, which have higher affinity for the antigen compared to those produced in the primary response. The secondary response is more rapid and robust, producing higher levels of antibodies that persist for a longer period.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Lag period: Correctly identified; the primary immune response has a longer lag period (4-10 days), while the secondary immune response has a shorter lag period (1-3 days).

 

Option B. Antibody response: Correctly identified; the secondary immune response is more potent than the primary immune response.

 

Option C. Isotype generated: Correctly identified; the primary response mainly produces IgM, while the secondary response mainly produces IgG.

 

Educational objective

choices.text: Ranitidine tablet before start of trip
Dimenhydrinate before start of trip
Scopolamine patch the night before trip
Omeprazole the night before and before starts of trip

questions.text: You and your friend plan for a mountain trip for the day after. What medication would you advise him to help with his motion sickness? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Scopolamine patch the night before trip

 

Scopolamine is an anticholinergic drug that is highly effective for the prevention and treatment of motion sickness. It works by blocking the muscarinic receptors in the central nervous system, which helps prevent the nausea and vomiting associated with motion sickness.

 

  • Transdermal Scopolamine Patch: The patch is typically applied behind the ear at least 4-5 hours before the trip and can provide continuous relief for up to 72 hours. This makes it highly convenient for trips that may last for several days

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ranitidine tablet before start of trip: Ranitidine is a histamine-2 receptor antagonist used to reduce stomach acid production. It is not effective for the prevention of motion sickness.

 

Option B. Dimenhydrinate before start of trip: Dimenhydrinate (Dramamine) is an antihistamine that can be effective for treating motion sickness, but it requires more frequent dosing compared to the scopolamine patch. It is taken orally and must be dosed every 4-6 hours.

 

Option D. Omeprazole the night before and before start of trip: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor used to reduce stomach acid production and treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It is not effective for preventing motion sickness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scopolamine, particularly in the form of a transdermal patch, is the drug of choice for the prevention of motion sickness. The patch should be applied the night before the trip to ensure it is effective in preventing the symptoms of motion sickness. Ranitidine and Omeprazole are not effective. Dimenhydrinate is an anti-histaminic drug which is not as effective as scopolamine.
